clinical_study.brief_title: Antiretroviral Treatment Outcomes in HIV-HBV Co-infected Patients in Southern Africa
clinical_study.official_title: Antiretroviral Treatment Outcomes in HIV-HBV Co-infected Patients in Southern Africa: a Collaborative Multi-country Prospective Cohort Analysis for International Epidemiologic Databases to Evaluate AIDS- Southern Africa (HIV/HBV-coinfection in IeDEA-SA)

collaborator.agency: Centre for Infectious Disease Research in Zambia

brief_summary.textblock: This is a prospective HIV cohort that aims to establish causes of liver disease among HIV-infected individuals in Zambia, including viral hepatitis and alcohol.

detailed_description.textblock: The study will take place during routinely scheduled ART visits as per Ministry of Health guidelines. Routinely collected programmatic data will be used to assess general HIV outcomes (CD4 response, loss to follow-up, death) as well as collecting study specific data (hepatitis testing, questionnaire regarding risk factors for hepatitis/liver disease, and non-invasive liver scan) to address other aims. The study will be implemented at two sites in Southern Africa (Zambia and Mozambique) with a total enrollment across all sites of 1,900 participants. The Zambia site will only enroll 900.

primary_outcome.description: A linear mixed effect model will be used to evaluate immunological response to ART in patients with and without viral hepatitis

secondary_outcome.description: Virological response will be evaluated using Cox regression analyses.
These events will be defined as an increase in the level of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) or aspartate aminotransferase (AST) > 5 time the upper limit within the first year of ART.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and one year after start of ART
secondary_outcome.description: The prevalence of liver fibrosis will be measured to compare HIV/hepatitis coinfected versus HIV monoinfected patients using transient elastography.
The presence of HBV drug resistance in co-infected patients who fail treatment after 1 year will be measured
The incidence of HBV infection during ART will be measured.
Describe prevalence of coinfection at ART initiation
Describe the proportion with unhealthy levels of drinking before and after ART

arm_group.description: 150-200 patients in Zambia and 250-300 across all sites
700-750 patients in Zambia and 1600-1700 across all sites

intervention.description: routine standard of care per Ministry of Health protocol including blood draws and examinations.

biospec_descr.textblock: Specimen storage is optional and participants will provide additional informed consent. The laboratory will store leftover blood specimens for up to 5 years for hepatitis related serologic, immunological, and virologic studies pending availability of funding. Use of specimens for any tests outside the realm of the goals and objectives of this study will require additional approval by the Zambian IRB.

study_pop.textblock: Enrollment of 1,900 consecutive patients starting ART (900 in Zambia and 1,000 in Mozambique) is planned.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- HIV-infected
- Male or female aged ≥18 years
- ART naïve
- ART eligible as defined by Zambian or WHO treatment guidelines
- Initiating an ART regimen including at least 3 drugs at one of the study sites.
- Willing to provide signed informed consent and be followed at the clinical site.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are not planning to remain in the catchment area from which they were recruited for the duration of the study
